title: Protocol for cytokine and uterine immune cell characterization in a mouse model of LPS-induced preterm birth
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
LPS injection
Timing: 30 min
C57BL/6J pregnant mice are given intraperitoneal LPS challenge on day 16 of gestation to induce a systemic inflammatory response, which may lead to preterm birth.
Critical: The following steps should be completed within a laminar flow hood.
Prepare the desired dose of LPS in 200 μL of injection saline solution to a final volume of 0.2 mL using a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Validate dose-response to LPS for each new batch, investigator, and mouse strain.
Note: In our hands, 25–75 μg LPS induces preterm birth in 100% of injected WT C57BL/6J mice, while 10 μg LPS produces ∼50% preterm birth rate and 5 μg LPS does not induce preterm birth.
Note: In this protocol, LPS dosing is not adjusted for mouse weight change in pregnancy, and in our experience is equally effective in C57BL/6J mice ranging in weight from 25-35 grams.
Note: In this protocol, mice were injected with 75 μg LPS. Uterine immune cell isolation was performed 6 h after injection, while IVCCA was performed 4 h after injection.
Vortex the LPS solution thoroughly to ensure the LPS does not adhere to the tube.
Draw up the solution into a syringe. Remove any air bubbles.
Critical: LPS is sensitive to light. Keep the syringe covered until you are ready to inject the mice.
Scruff the pregnant mouse in the non-dominant hand and hold it parallel to the work surface.
Inject the mouse intraperitoneally.
Position the needle with the bevel facing upward between the second set of nipples and nearly parallel to the abdomen.
Inject at the midline to avoid injecting into the uterine horns.
Critical: Perform uterine immune cell isolation 6 h after injection. Perform IVCCA 4 h after injection.
Uterine immune cell isolation
Timing: 9 h

Here we describe the collection of uterine tissue from C57BL/6J mice 6 h after LPS injection followed by isolation of immune cells using enzymatic digestion. After isolation, the cells will be plated for immunostaining.
Note: Prepare Digestion Buffer with 20°C–22°C RPMI 1640 immediately before experiment.
Under a laminar flow hood, add 1 mL of cRPMI to a 15 mL centrifuge tube for each animal. Keep the tube on ice until step 9.
Collect uterine sample 6 h after injection of LPS or saline control.
Euthanize the mouse and open the abdominal cavity.
Remove the uterus.
Discard fetal and placental tissue, retaining the uterine tissue.
Place the uterine tissue in the 15 mL centrifuge tube with cRPMI.
Mince the uterine tissue with scissors.
Note: Perform the following steps in a laminar flow hood.
Add 1 mL of digestion buffer to the minced uterus.
Incubate in the orbital shaker at 37°C for 45 min at 225 RPM (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).

Figure 1. Depiction of minced and digested tissue after step 10
Successfully minced and digested tissue from non-pregnant (left) and pregnant (right) uterus.
Filter the sample through a 70 μm filter into 50 mL conical centrifuge tubes.
Rinse the 15 mL centrifuge tube with 10 mL of cRPMI.
Pour through the filter for a total volume of 12 mL in the 50 mL centrifuge tube.
Centrifuge at 930 × g (2000 RPM) for 4 min at 4°C (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3050-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Depiction of cell pellet after step 14
Immune cell pellet after filtration and centrifugation.
Discard supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 1 mL of ACK.
Incubate for 1 min at room temperature (20°C–22°C).
Centrifuge at 930 × g (2000 RPM) for 4 min at 4°C.
Discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 3 mL of cRPMI.

Centrifuge at 930 × g (2000 RPM) for 4 min at 4°C (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3050-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Depiction of cell pellet after step 21
Immune cell pellet after ACK incubation and washing with cRPMI.
Discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 1 mL of cRPMI.
Remove 10 μL and add it to 90 μL of Trypan blue in a new tube or plate.
Place 10 μL of the cell suspension in a hemocytometer and count immune cells (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3050-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Depiction of uterine immune cells in hemocytometer at step 25
Several examples of immune cells are labeled with red arrows. Scale bar denotes 250 µm.
Centrifuge the 50 mL tube at 930 × g (2000 RPM) for 4 min at 4°C.
Resuspend the cell pellet in cRPMI at a maximum concentration of 10 × 106 cells/mL.
Plate up to 2 × 106 cells (up to 200 μL) in a 96-well round bottom plate.
Plate two extra wells with isolated uterine immune cells for unstained control and viability control (Zombie UV).
Critical: Plate the same number of cells per well for each animal or biological replicate. If cell yields are variable, multiple wells can be plated for higher yield samples. Plate a minimum of 50,000 cells per well.
Immunostaining of immune cells from uterine tissue for flow cytometry
Timing: 2 h
In this section we describe the process of staining single cell suspensions for flow cytometry. This protocol describes the procedure for surface marker staining. Additionally, immune cells can be stimulated before staining to evaluate intracellular marker expression or capacity for intracellular cytokine production. For details on stimulation, intracellular staining, and cytokine production gating strategy, please refer to our previously published protocol.2[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]
Critical: Complete the following steps in the hood with the light off.

Note: Prepare the Surface Marker Master Mix at the end of the incubation period from the previous step.
Add one small drop (∼50 μL) of compensation beads to 11 wells (one for each staining antibody, excluding viability control). These will be the single-stained control wells.
Centrifuge the plate for 7 min at 625 × g (1600 RPM) at 4°C to pellet cells and beads.
Aspirate the supernatant from each well.
Note: Avoid touching the cell pellet while aspirating.
Add 50 μL of Surface Stain Master Mix to each sample well.
Add 50 μL of FACS Staining Buffer to each single-stained control well, the viability control well, and the unstained control well.
Add the 1× amount of each individual antibody (see list in Surface Stain Master Mix) to its single-stained control well.
Add the 1× amount of Zombie UV Dye to the pelleted cells in the viability control well.
Pipet each well up and down to mix.
Incubate the plate for 30 min at room temperature (20°C–22°C) in the dark.
Alternatives: Surface stain can be incubated at 4°C instead of room temperature to decrease nonspecific binding.
Centrifuge the plate at 930 × g (2000 RPM) for 4 min at 4°C. Aspirate the supernatant.
Resuspend pellets in 200 μL of cold FACS Washing Buffer by pipetting up and down.
Centrifuge the plate at 930 × g (2000 RPM) for 4 min at 4°C. Aspirate the supernatant.
Resuspend pellets in 100 μL of BD Cytofix by pipetting up and down.
Incubate for 30 min at 4°C in the dark.
Centrifuge at 930 × g (2000 RPM) for 4 min at 4°C. Aspirate the supernatant.
Resuspend pellets in 200 μL of cold FACS Washing Buffer.
Transfer to flow tubes for acquisition.
Acquire the data with a flow cytometer.
In-Vivo Cytokine Capture Assay (IVCCA)

Timing: 10.5 h
Mouse serum cytokines are captured in vivo and quantified after LPS injection via ELISA. The protocol described here is our optimization of the original protocol published by Finkelman et al.3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]
Prepare IVCCA Antibody Master Mix in a 50 mL conical tube.
Draw up 200 μL of the solution into a syringe (one syringe per mouse). Remove any air bubbles.
Note: The antibody solution dosing is not adjusted for mouse weight and in our experience is equally effective in mice ranging in weight from 15-60 grams.
Inject the mice intraperitoneally.
Position the needle with the bevel facing upward between the second set of nipples and nearly parallel to the abdomen.
After 3 h, inject the mice with LPS following the protocol above (steps 1–5).
Collect blood 7 h after antibody injection (4 h after LPS injection) and place it into microtainer serum separator tube.
Note: This procedure is terminal: collect as much blood as possible (usually about 500 μL to 1 mL).
Centrifuge at 10,600 × g (10,000 RPM) for 7 min at 20°C–22°C.
Place serum in 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Pause point: Serum can be stored at ‒80°C. Multiple freeze-thaw cycles may affect the level of cytokine detected.
Critical: Ensure plate is coated (see before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin], step 5) before thawing the serum, if frozen.
Thaw serum on ice.
Note: Prepare dilution buffer while the serum thaws.
Make biotinylated standards.
Add the below amounts of recombinant protein and injection antibody to 10 or 18 μL of dilution buffer as noted below.
table:files/protocols_protocol_3050_9.csv
Incubate for 10 min at 20°C–22°C.
After incubation, add enough dilution buffer to each standard to reach the noted final concentration.
Make serial dilutions for each standard.

Remove 25 μL of diluted standard and add it to 75 μL of dilution buffer for a 1:4 dilution.
Repeat (b) 5 more times for the 1:16, 1:64, 1:128, 1:256, and 1:512 standards.
After thawing, add 125 μL serum to 375 μL of dilution buffer for a 1:4 dilution.
Note: Different genotypes of mice may respond differently to LPS and require different serum dilutions to accurately measure cytokine production. Additionally, serum concentrations of individual cytokines vary. Adjust serum dilutions as needed between genotypes and cytokines to keep samples within the range of the standard curve.
Wash the plate 5 times with wash buffer.
Alternatives: We recommend use of an automated plate washer for consistency, but plates can also be washed manually using a wash bottle.
Load 30 μL of each of the standard dilutions onto the plate in duplicate.
Load 30 μL of dilution buffer onto the plate in duplicate as a blank.
Load 30 μL of the diluted serum onto the plate in duplicate.
Incubate at 20°C–22°C for 40 min.
Note: Prepare the streptavidin-horseradish peroxidase (SA-HRP) by adding 1 μL SA-HRP to 20 mL dilution buffer while the plate incubates. Aliquots can be stored at ‒20°C for future use.
After incubation, wash the plate 5 times with wash buffer.
Add 30 μL diluted SA-HRP to each well and incubate for 25 min at 20°C–22°C.
Wash the plate 10 times with wash buffer.
Add 150 μL of 1× TBS to each well.
Note: Prepare the developer at this point.
Remove the TBS and add 150 μL of the developer to each well.
Read the plate on a luminometer at 425 nm.
Critical: Read the plate immediately after adding the developer. If you have multiple plates, add developer to the plates one at a time as you are ready to read them.
